verse: Jehoshaphat ·died [lay down/slept with his fathers/ancestors] and was buried with his ·ancestors [fathers] in the City of David [Jerusalem]. Then his son Jehoram became king in his place.
Jehoram’s brothers were Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariahu, Michael, and Shephatiah. They were the sons of Jehoshaphat king of ·Judah [Israel; 12:6].

Jehoshaphat gave his sons many gifts of silver, gold, and ·valuable [precious] things, and he gave them ·strong, walled [fortified] cities in Judah. But Jehoshaphat gave the kingdom to Jehoram, because he was the ·first son [firstborn].
When Jehoram took control of his father’s kingdom and ·made himself secure [established himself], he killed all his brothers with the sword and also killed some of the ·leaders [officials] of Judah.
He was thirty-two years old when he began to ·rule [reign], and he ·ruled [reigned] eight years in Jerusalem.

He ·followed [walked] in the ways of the kings of Israel, just as the ·family [house] of Ahab had done, because he married Ahab’s daughter. Jehoram did ·what the Lord said was wrong [evil in the Lord’s sight/eyes].

But the Lord would not destroy David’s ·family [house] because of the ·agreement [covenant; treaty] he had made with David. He had promised ·that one of David’s descendants would always rule [to give a lamp to David and his descendants/sons forever; here a lamp symbolizes a dynasty].
In Jehoram’s time, Edom ·broke away from [revolted/rebelled against] Judah’s ·rule [reign] and ·chose [set up] their own king.

So Jehoram went to Edom with all his ·commanders [officers] and chariots. The Edomites surrounded him and his chariot ·commanders [officers], but Jehoram got up and attacked the Edomites at night [the implication is that Jehoram is victorious, but the next verse suggests otherwise; see 2 Kin. 8:21].

From then until now the country of Edom has ·fought against [been free from] the ·rule [reign] of Judah. At the same time the people of Libnah also ·broke away from [rebelled/revolted against] Jehoram because Jehoram ·left [abandoned; forsook] the Lord, the God of his ·ancestors [fathers].

Jehoram also built ·places to worship gods [high places; 11:15] on the hills in Judah. He led the people of Jerusalem to ·sin [commit adultery; play the harlot], and he led the people of Judah ·away from the Lord [astray].
Then Jehoram received this letter from Elijah the prophet:
The Lord caused the Philistines and the Arabs who lived near the ·Cushites [Ethiopians] to be ·angry with [stirred in their spirits against] Jehoram.
So the Philistines and Arabs attacked and invaded Judah and carried away all the wealth of Jehoram’s ·palace [house], as well as his sons and wives. Only Jehoram’s youngest son, Ahaziah, was left.
After these things happened, the Lord ·gave Jehoram [struck/afflicted/smote him with] a disease in his ·intestines [bowels] that could not be cured.

After he was sick for two years, Jehoram’s ·intestines [bowels] ·came out [protruded] because of the disease, and he died in ·terrible pain [agony]. The people did not make a funeral fire to honor Jehoram as they had done for his ·ancestors [fathers].

Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he ·ruled [reigned] eight years in Jerusalem. No one ·was sad [regretted] when he died. He was buried in the City of David [Jerusalem], but not in the ·graves for [tombs of] the kings.
